div1.p: CThe chronology begins in 1898 with the Spanish-American War and ends in March 1901.

div1.head: Chronology of Cuba regarding yellow fever, [19--]

p.add:
Penny chronology
For Mrs. Penny's book
“US”
Cuba re yellow fever

div1.p:
1898 (During War) Major Gorgas in charge yellow fever camp at Siboney.
This Camp was later (1898) burned, on Gorgas' advice.

Jan. 1899--Gorgas Chief Sanitary Officer of Havana (may have been ap-
pointed latter part of 1898)

Jan. 1899, Carter ordered to Cuba, as Chief Quarantine Officer, to
prevent introduction yellow fever to States, by work at
source of trouble.

1899. Gorgas “cleaned up” Havana (in accordance with the belief that
yellow fever was a filth disease.

1899 (latter part) Spanish immigrants began coming to Cuba in large
numbers.

1899-1900: Yellow fever epidemic in Havana, as result of introduction
large number of non-immunes (above)
1899-1900: Finlay, Gorgas, Carter, Albertini on Board of Diagnosis (y. f.)

June, 1900: Walter Reed came to Cuba, as head of Reed Board of investigation
Board: Walter Reed, Chairman
James Carroll
Jesse Lazear
Aristides Agramonte (Cuban)

Mem. Lazear and Agramonte were already in Cuba when Reed and
Carroll came down.
Sept. 25, 1900: Lazear died of yellow fever.
October. 1900: Reed announced mosquito conveyance of yellow fever.

March 1901: Gorgas began work of freeing Havana from yellow fever,
basing his sanitary measures on the new knowledge of
mosquito conveyance. Work a brilliant success by Sept.

For this work Gorgas was promoted by Special Act of
Congress to full Colonel (passing over the grade of
Lieutenant Colonel)
